title: 113_s2609
content: The "Marketplace and Internet Tax Fairness Act" allows for the collection of sales and use taxes. The Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement authorizes Member States to require sellers to collect and remit sales taxes for remote sales. Non-Member States can also collect taxes despite not being part of the agreement. The Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement allows states to mandate sellers to collect and remit sales taxes for remote sales, even for sellers not qualifying for the small seller exception. This authority can begin no earlier than six months after the state enacts legislation specifying the applicable taxes and products/services. The Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement allows states to mandate sellers to collect and remit sales taxes for remote sales. Sellers must comply with minimum simplification requirements, including having a single entity responsible for tax administration, audits, and return processing within the state. The Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement mandates remote sellers to file tax returns with a single entity responsible for tax administration. States cannot require remote sellers to file returns more frequently than nonremote sellers or impose additional requirements. Local jurisdictions cannot require remote sellers to submit tax returns or collect taxes beyond what is specified. Uniform sales and use tax base is required among states and local taxing jurisdictions. The Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement requires remote sellers to comply with sourcing definitions, provide taxability information, exemptions, and software for calculating and filing sales and use taxes. The Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement requires remote sellers to comply with sourcing definitions, provide taxability information, exemptions, and certified software providers to calculate and file sales and use taxes in qualified states. Remote sellers are relieved from liability for tax errors made by certified software providers. The Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement relieves remote sellers and certified software providers from liability for tax errors caused by misleading or inaccurate information provided by the State or locality. They are also given 90 days notice of any rate changes. The Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement provides 90 days notice of any rate changes or product/service updates by the State or locality. Remote sellers are relieved from tax liability if proper notice is not given. States can require tax collection from remote sellers with over $1,000,000 in total remote sales annually. When determining if the threshold is met, gross annual receipts from remote sales of related persons must be aggregated. Ownership relationships designed to avoid these rules are also considered. SEC. 102. LIMITATIONS. SEC. 102. LIMITATIONS. In General, this title does not subject sellers to various taxes other than sales and use taxes, does not affect tax application, and does not change State authority on taxes. It does not create nexus or change nexus standards. Sellers can choose their software provider. No impact on State licensing or regulation. The provisions of this title prohibit states from imposing new taxes on products or services not previously taxed. It only applies to remote sales, not intrastate sales, and states must comply with intrastate provisions of the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement. No Effect on Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Act. The Act does not change or preempt the Mobile Telecommunications Sourcing Act. Limitation on Initial Collection of Sales and Use Taxes From Remote Sales. States cannot start collecting taxes under this title until 1 year after the enactment of the Act, and only between October 1 and December 31 of the first calendar year after enactment. SEC. 103. DEFINITIONS AND SPECIAL RULES. The title defines "certified software provider" as a person providing software for tax compliance, "locality" as a political subdivision, and "Member State" as defined in the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement. The Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement defines terms like "person," "remote sale," "remote seller," and "sourced" for sales tax purposes. The remote sale is sourced to the purchaser's delivery location or address provided by the purchaser. If no location is specified, it is sourced to the customer's known address or the seller's address. States must comply with the Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement. The Streamlined Sales and Use Tax Agreement applies to states, territories, tribal organizations, and certain agreements related to sales and use taxes. Title II of the document is the Internet Tax Freedom Act, which extends the act. The document also includes provisions on severability and preemption, stating that if any part of the title is deemed unconstitutional, the rest of the title will not be affected. It also clarifies that the title does not preempt or limit any powers of states or local jurisdictions unless specified otherwise. The Internet Tax Freedom Act is extended until November 1, 2024, with provisions for grandfathering states that tax internet access.
